issues.title: Is new SDP actually necessary?
issues.author: steely-glint
issues.body:
I haven't looked at this in depth, but I think that all the info you need to decide how to handle 
a=fingerprint {cert/raw}
is already in the DTLS hello(s).

We still need to establish what those rules are, but I don't think we need new SDP.

comments.author: JonathanLennox
comments.body: The issue is that, while RFC 8122 makes it clear that SDP can carry multiple fingerprints with the same hash function and different values, this wasn't clear in the original RFC 4572; and some implementations may still not support that, and misbehave if they receive it.

comments.author: steely-glint
comments.body:
Ok, so to amplify your point:
The offerer needs to send both fingerprints because it doesn't _yet_ know what the answerer is capable of.
Some implementations can't cope with multiple a=fingerprint lines but will ignore any a= that it doesn't know about and so will continue to work only if we use a=raw-fingerprint for the the raw key fingerprint.

Is that right?

comments.author: JonathanLennox
comments.body:
Yes, that's what I was thinking.

I had a section on that in my original version of the draft but I took it out before publication, probably I should have left it in.  I'll put it back if I publish another version, but given the expires issue you raised at https://github.com/JonathanLennox/raw-key-fingerprints/issues/3, I may not.

issues.title: Add 'expires' to the security discussion.
issues.author: steely-glint
issues.body:
The only other property that webRTC exposes from the RTCCertificate object is 'expires' .
This can usefully be combined with PeerConnection.generateCertificate() to create a medium term pairing/trust relationship.

The security discussion should cover this.

comments.author: JonathanLennox
comments.body: Ah, that's a good point.  I don't think this is easily modifiable.  So at this point I'm thinking that using https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-davidben-x509-alg-none-00.html is a better solution.

issues.title: Possible follow on should cover webRTC usage of stored certificates
issues.author: steely-glint
issues.body: Whilst no webRTC identity providers exist there are folks (pi.pe for example)  who are using the ability to generate a certificate with a defined expiry date, store it and then re-use it multiple times as a sort of poor-man's (TOFU) identity assertion. Whilst might be seen as W3C territory this draft casually nixes several webRTC api points, the least it can do is to admit it ;-)
